docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It is understandable that Jane Brody would be so negative about low-carbohydrate diets, since her books advocate a completely different approach to healthy eating. But low-carbohydrate diets really do work and eating (even complex) carbohydrates really can be fattening.
docs.abstract: Marian Russell letter comments on Jane E Brody's May 25 Personal Health column criticizing low-carbohydrate diets

docs.lead_paragraph: Doctors usually evaluate patients' vulnerability to serious disease by inquiring about risk factors like cigarette smoking, obesity, hypertension and high cholesterol. But they might be better off asking how much money those patients make, how many years they spent in school and where they stand relative to others in their offices and communities.

headline.main: For Good Health, It Helps To Be Rich and Important

docs.abstract: Research demonstrates that social class--as measured not just by income but also by education and other markers of relative status--is one of most powerful predictors of health, more powerful than genetics, exposure to carcinogens, even smoking; shows that with wide variety of illnesses, the higher the rung on the socioeconomic ladder, the lower the risk; relationship holds even at upper reaches of society, where it might seem that abundance of resources would even things out; gap in life expectancy between blacks and white decreases substantially once socioeconomic status is taken into account; graph (M)
docs.snippet: Doctors usually evaluate patients' vulnerability to serious disease by inquiring about risk factors like cigarette smoking, obesity, hypertension and high cholesterol.    But they might be better off asking how much money those patients make, how...

docs.lead_paragraph: Why does a tragedy always seem necessary to alert people to consider safety issues that should be a matter of course? Such a tragedy occurred last summer when 10-year-old Jeremy Scheinfeld of New Rochelle, N.Y., drowned while attending an upstate sleep-away camp. According to a lawsuit filed by his parents, Jodi and Robert Scheinfeld, the incident took place during a game off camp grounds that required Jeremy to jump into swirling water wearing hiking clothes and shoes. Though he could swim, he became enmeshed in underwater branches and could not free himself. It took 18 hours to find his body.

headline.main: Going Beyond the Obvious For a Safer Summer Camp

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on steps parents can take to help insure their children's safety while going to summer camp; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Until recently, very few people lived to be more than 100. But with the number of centenarians rocketing upward, statisticians and scientists have begun studying them -- and challenging some of the conventional wisdom about the very old. These are not necessarily people at the end of the line, deteriorating into extreme age. Rather, many show patterns of health that are as surprising as they are mysterious. For example, the rate at which people die rises steadily from middle age up through the 80's. But then, death rates decline. After age 110, the death rate drops back to that for people in their 80's.

headline.main: Life at Age 100 Is Surprisingly Healthy

docs.abstract: Statisticians and scientists are increasingly studying centenarians, with their numbers steadily rising; many of such older people shows patterns of health that are as surprising as they are mysterious; for example, rate at which people die rises steadily from middle age up through the 80's; but then, death rates decline; after age 110, death rate drops back to that for people in their 80's; photo shows six generations of one family, ranging from Sara Knauss, 118, to her great-great-great-grandson Bradley Patton, 3 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The reporting in the Weight Loss Report neglects to mention an important psychological factor involved. People often eat because they are depressed, lonely or anxious. This type of eating leads to weight gain because people eat beyond their physical needs to cope with emotional stresses.
docs.abstract: Genevieve Pham-Kanter letter comments on psychological factors in weight gain (May 25 report on weight loss)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration recently issued new regulations for labeling, testing and manufacturing sun protection products. The rules do away with terms like ''sun block,'' ''waterproof'' and ''all-day protection.'' All over-the-counter sun protection products will be called ''sunscreen.'' Those that resist water will be classified either as ''water resistant'' or ''very water resistant'' on product packaging. The Federal agency also approved a list of active ingredients for over-the-counter sunscreens. In order to be considered ''active,'' ingredients have to ''absorb, reflect or scatter radiation in the UV range at wavelengths of 290 to 400 nanometers.'' UVB rays, which induce sunburn and skin cancer, fall into the 290 to 320 nanometer range, while UVA rays, which affect aging and cause skin cancer, range from 320 to 400. Some of the sunscreen-approved ingredients that the agency listed were zinc oxide, titanium dioxide, dioxybenzone and avobenzone. There were 18 in all.

headline.main: In Time for the Beach, New Sunscreen Rules

docs.abstract: FDA issues new regulations for labeling, testing and manufacturing sun-protection products (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study suggests that low-dose hormone replacement therapy combined with calcium and vitamin D supplements may increase bone mineral density in women over 65 by at least as much as the higher hormone doses now recommended but without unpleasant side effects. The study, conducted by researchers at Creighton University in Omaha, is of particular importance in osteoporosis research because it helps establish that increased levels of calcium and vitamin D can enhance the effectiveness of estrogen. Osteoporosis, which often goes unnoticed until a person suffers a debilitating fracture, is the most common bone disease in America, particularly among postmenopausal women. Many women avoid hormone replacement therapy, or H.R.T., which helps prevent osteoporosis, because of side effects and increased risk of more serious complications.

headline.main: New Therapy Builds Bone Without Unpleasant Side Effects

docs.abstract: New study suggests that low-dose hormone replacement therapy combined with calcium and vitamin D supplements may increase bone mineral density in women over 65 by at least as much as higher hormone doses now recommended but without unpleasant side effects; study, conducted by researchers at Creighton University in Omaha, is of particular importance in osteoporosis research because it helps establish that increased levels of calcium and vitamin D can enhance effectiveness of estrogen (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Whether trying to reach stardom in high school sports, working to achieve a fashionable lean-but-muscular look or suffering from a deep psychological disorder, teen-age girls are using illegal anabolic steroids in sharply increasing numbers, health authorities say. The increased usage among girls, which some researchers attribute in part to a kind of reverse anorexia, has caught up to levels that began to be established by boys in the 1980's. And steroid use, researchers say, exposes girls to the same severe health risks, but with the added potential of destroying their ability to bear children.

headline.main: Steroid Use by Teen-Age Girls Is Rising

docs.abstract: Health authorities report that teen-age girls are using anabolic steroids in sharply increasing numbers, whether trying to reach stardom in high school sports, working to achieve a fashionable lean-but-muscular look or suffering from deep psychological disorder; some researchers attribute trend in part to a kind of reverse anorexia; researchers warn that steroid use exposes girls to same severe health risks that boys face, but with added potential of destroying their ability to have children (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hospitals may draw up to 10 times more blood than they need for medical tests, according to a survey of 19 hospitals published in the current issue of The New England Journal of Medicine. Dr. Jocelyn M. Hicks, chairwoman of the Department of Laboratory Medicine at Children's National Medical Center in Washington, did the study after spending two weeks in an intensive care unit. She discovered that so much of her blood was taken for tests that the volume of oxygen-carrying red cells in her blood dropped to 31 percent from 43 percent. The normal range for a woman is 37 percent to 47 percent.

headline.main: Extra Blood Often Taken For Testing

docs.abstract: Survey of 19 hospitals finds that hospitals may draw up to 10 times more blood than they need for medical tests (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Jane Brody in her Personal Health column continues to attack the Atkins diet (''Doubts Fail to Deter the Diet Revolution'') despite 40 years of positive clinical experience and hundreds of publications supporting the diet's safety and efficacy.
